description.narrative: Pacific Infrastructure is a newly formed Holding company which will own several companies in Colombia dedicated to logistics and infrastructure for the Oil & Gas Sector. The two initial project companies are: Puerto Bahia S.A., a wholly owned subsidiary that is building a bulk liquids terminal in the Bay of Cartagena specialized in handling crude oil and other hydrocarbons. The port will have an installed throughput capacity of 300,000 barrels and a storage capacity of more than 3 million barrels. The 155 hectares site will also include a general cargo handling facility, initially for Ro-Ro, dry bulk, project and general cargo and includes a 45 hectares Industrial Free Trade Zone. Olecar, a greenfield 130 km pipeline that connects Puerto Bahia with Coveñas, the node where most of the existing trunk oil pipelines in Colombia lead to. The pipeline has been designed with a throughput capacity of 300,000 barrels. Pacific Infrastructure is expected to own 100% of Puerto Bahia and 50% of Olecar. Ecopetrol has been invited to participate as shareholder of the remaining 50% in Olecar. The company was created with the specific purpose of developing these projects, and invest in any other infrastructure projects which can be developed by the Group.

The project will contribute to Colombia''s competitiveness in the port sector and help overcome infrastructure bottlenecks in the oil export activity: (i) will provide service to oil crude producers that are having difficulty in accessing the international markets without restrictions, (ii) will generate resilience to the overall crude oil export logistics (ii) will provide needed additional capacity for bulk cargo handling with state of the art technology. The main development impact which will be tracked in both projects, is the throughput volume seen in both the port and the pipeline. Pacific Infrastructure will create additional jobs in Cartagena. It will also support the Government with increased concession payments and taxes.

name.narrative: Both projects will be constructed in the Northern Atlantic Coast of Colombia. Puerto Bahia will be located on a 155 Ha site on Isla Baru in the Cartagena Bay. The site has frontage both on the Bay itself that can accommodate deep draft ocean-going vessels and on the Canal connecting to the Magdalena River (Canal del Dique) that enables the handling of barge tows and other river craft. Olecar is a 130 kilometer pipeline, which will be constructed between Puerto Bahia and Coveñas. Through the mayority of its extension, the pipeline will be side-by-side with an existing Ecopetrol pipeline.
